conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to \( t_2 \), we can use the v-t (velocity vs. time) graph provided.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the velocity-time curve.
From the graph, observe the velocity-time curve of Object B. The curve starts with a positive slope, decreases to a minimum (negative slope), and then increases again (positive slope).

premise: The curve starts with a positive slope, decreases to a minimum, and then increases again.
conclusion: Initially, the slope of the curve is positive and decreasing, indicating a decreasing positive acceleration.

premise: At the turning point around \( t_1 \), the slope becomes negative.
conclusion: At the turning point around \( t_1 \), the slope becomes negative, indicating negative acceleration (deceleration).

premise: Beyond \( t_1 \), the slope starts to increase.
conclusion: Beyond \( t_1 \), the slope starts to increase, indicating negative acceleration is decreasing (eventually approaching zero acceleration).
The red tangent lines illustrate the slope at different points on the curve.
The first tangent line at the start has a positive slope.
The tangent line at \( t_1 \) has a negative slope.
The tangent line at \( t_2 \) shows a slope that is less negative (or closer to zero).

premise: Initially, the slope of the curve is positive and decreasing.
conclusion: Initially, the acceleration is positive and decreasing.

premise: At \( t_1 \), the velocity is at a minimum.
conclusion: It becomes zero at \( t_1 \) when the velocity is at a minimum.

premise: Beyond \( t_1 \), the slope starts to increase.
conclusion: Beyond \( t_1 \), the acceleration becomes negative and increases towards zero at \( t_2 \).

premise: The analysis of the slope changes from 0 to \( t_2 \).
conclusion: Therefore, the acceleration of B first decreases and then increases.
